# Arpeggio: 11th in D# (Shape: C)

An arpeggio is the playing of the tones of a chord in succession rather than simultaneously. It is typically used as a tool for guitarists to outline the harmony of a song or to create a melodic line. The 11th arpeggio is an extension of the chord that adds the 11th note on top of the basic triad.

## Notes and Intervals
The 11th arpeggio in the key of D# consists of the following notes: D#, G#, A#, C#, F. The interval pattern for this arpeggio is as follows: the root note (D#), the major third (G#), the perfect fifth (A#), the major seventh (C#), and the perfect 11th (F).

## Genre and Musical Flavor
This particular arpeggio, with its major 7th and 11th intervals, has a lush and jazzy sound. It is often used in genres such as jazz, neo-soul, and R&B to add color and sophistication to chord progressions and solos. The 11th arpeggio can evoke feelings of warmth, richness, and a sense of elegance in musical compositions.

## Songs
Here are three songs that feature the 11th arpeggio in D#:
1. "Lush Life" by Billy Strayhorn - This jazz standard showcases the use of 11th arpeggios in its harmonic progression and melody.
2. "Don't You Worry 'Bout a Thing" by Stevie Wonder - This funky R&B tune incorporates 11th arpeggios in its chord voicings and keyboard solos.
3. "Spain" by Chick Corea - This fusion jazz masterpiece includes colorful 11th arpeggios in its intricate chord changes and improvisational sections.
